data.title: Organic Chemical Formulas
data.statement:
Organic chemical formulas always contain the elements Carbon and Hydrogen.
The way the elements are listed in a chemical formula is:
-Carbon first
-Followed by hydrogen
-Then followed by other elements listed in alphabetical order.
The number following an element means the number of that element, but if there is only 1 of that element, do not write the number.

Example:
Methane has 1 Carbon and 4 Hydrogen, so the formula is CH4 because Carbon (C) comes before Hydrogen (H), and there are 4 Hydrogen atoms (so 4).
Another example:
Acetaminophen has 8 Carbon, 9 Hydrogen, 1 Nitrogen, and 2 Oxygen Atoms, so the chemical formula is C8H9NO2 because carbon comes first, followed by hydrogen. Nitrogen is listed before oxygen alphabetically.

Given a list of atomic symbols that make up an organic compound, write its chemical formula.

data.stubGenerator:
read n:int
loop n read s:string(10)
write Chemical formula - C, H, Alphabetical order
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> An integer [[n]] representing the number of atoms in the organic compound.
<<Next [[n]] lines:>> A string [[s]] representing the atomic symbol of an element that is part of the organic compound.
data.outputDescription: <<Line 1:>> A chemical formula of the organic compound in the correct order.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Organic chemical formulas always contain the elements Carbon and Hydrogen.
The way the elements are listed in a chemical formula is:
-Carbon first
-Followed by hydrogen
-Then followed by other elements listed in alphabetical order.
The number following an element means the number of that element, but if there is only 1 of that element, do not write the number.

Example:
Methane has 1 Carbon and 4 Hydrogen, so the formula is CH4 because Carbon (C) comes before Hydrogen (H), and there are 4 Hydrogen atoms (so 4).
Another example:
Acetaminophen has 8 Carbon, 9 Hydrogen, 1 Nitrogen, and 2 Oxygen Atoms, so the chemical formula is C8H9NO2 because carbon comes first, followed by hydrogen. Nitrogen is listed before oxygen alphabetically.

Given a list of atomic symbols that make up an organic compound, write its chemical formula.
Input
Line 1: An integer n representing the number of atoms in the organic compound.
Next n lines: A string s representing the atomic symbol of an element that is part of the organic compound.
Output
Line 1: A chemical formula of the organic compound in the correct order.
Constraints
1 ≤ n ≤ 75
1 ≤ length of s ≤ 2
Example
Input
3
H
C
H
Output
CH2
